arm_group.description: Subjects will receive daily cue exposure sessions.
Subjects will receive weekly cue exposure sessions.
Subjects will be exposed to food cues in a single context.
Subjects will be exposed to food cues in multiple contexts.
Subjects will be tasting food during cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will not be tasting food during cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will receive only the cue exposure treatment during the clinical trial phase of the study.
Subjects will receive the cue exposure treatment as an adjunct to the family-based behavioral treatment for weight loss (current gold standard treatment).

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to optimize an obesity treatment program targeting overweight
      8-12 year old children using "Cue Exposure Training".

clinical_study.brief_title: Learning Theory to Improve Obesity Treatment

detailed_description.textblock:
The goal of the Cue Exposure program is to train children to resist cues to eat unhealthy
      foods.  Through a series of experimental studies, the investigators will evaluate how many
      weekly treatment visits there should be, whether children should be exposed to a single food
      or multiple foods during treatment, whether to use partial reinforcement or not, whether
      visits should be daily or weekly, and whether the exposures should be in single or multiple
      contexts. The investigators will be recruiting parent-child dyads in the San Diego community
      to participate in 8 to 16 weekly or daily treatment sessions either in their home, community
      center, or our lab, depending on the treatment arm.  Parents and children will complete
      baseline and post-treatment assessments consisting of collecting psychophysiological data,
      completing laboratory tasks, and completing questionnaires.  The investigators will be
      evaluating which treatment condition reduces overeating (as measured by our laboratory
      tasks).

      Following these experimental studies, the investigators will use the most promising
      treatment and conduct a proof of concept study to look at the acceptability and feasibility
      of this intervention with existing behavioral weight loss treatments.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Response to an advertisement for the study,

          -  An overweight or obese child in the family who is between the ages of 8 and 12,

          -  The 8-12 year old child must be above the 85th BMI % for age and gender,

          -  Parent willing to participate and attend all meetings,

          -  Parent who can read at a minimum of a 5th grade level in English,

          -  Parent and child willing to commit to attendance and assessments,

          -  Child who eats in the absence of hunger.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Major child psychiatric disorder diagnoses,

          -  An obese child over the 99.9th BMI %

          -  Child or parent diagnoses of diabetes for which physician supervision of diet is
             needed or diagnosis of serious current physical diseases (such as cancer, multiple
             sclerosis, lupus) which could significantly decrease their ability to participate in
             the intervention (parent report),

          -  Child taking a medication that can affect cognitive functioning, such as attention,
             concentration, or mental status.

          -  Family with restrictions on types of food, such as food allergies, or religious or
             ethnic practices that limit the foods available in the home (these restrictions
             affect their ability participate in the food exposures because it would limit the
             variety of foods available to do exposures with),

          -  Child with an active eating disorder (based on parent and child self-report)

          -  Major parent psychiatric or eating disorder.

intervention.description: Subjects will receive 8 sessions of cue exposure treatment.

This version of the cue exposure treatment that will be provided in the clinical trial context will consist of the optimized components of the treatment as determined by the results of the experimental phase of this study.
This is the current gold standard treatment for behavioral weight loss that will be used to compare to the cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will receive 16 sessions of cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will be exposed to the same set of 4 foods in each cue exposure treatment session.
Subjects will be exposed to a different set of 4 foods in each cue exposure treatment session.
Subjects will receive 8 or 16 daily cue exposure treatment sessions.
Subjects will receive 8 or 16 weekly cue exposure treatment sessions.
Subjects will be asked to taste the food during cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will NOT be asked to taste the food during cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will be exposed to foods in a single context during cue exposure treatment.
Subjects will be exposed to foods in multiple contexts during cue exposure treatment.

clinical_study.official_title: Learning Theory to Improve Obesity Treatment (Intervention for Regulation of Cues)

primary_outcome.description: Reduce overeating or eating in the absence of hunger in response to food cues.  Habituation to food cues.
primary_outcome.measure: Overeating (Eating in the absence of hunger)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 1 week after treatment completion

primary_outcome.description: Salivation/swallowing using EMG (electromyography), skin conductance, heart rate and heart rate variability.
primary_outcome.measure: Psychophysiological measures of responsivity to food cues
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 1 week after treatment completion

primary_outcome.description: Participants will rate their cravings on a scale of 1-10.
primary_outcome.measure: Level of self-reported cravings in response to palatable food cues.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 1 week after treatment completion

primary_outcome.description: Reduce overeating or eating in the absence of hunger in response to food cues. Habituation to food cues.
primary_outcome.measure: Overeating (Eating in the absence of hunger)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 6 months after treatment completion

primary_outcome.description: Salivation/swallowing using EMG (electromyography), skin conductance, heart rate and heart rate variability.
primary_outcome.measure: Psychophysiological measures of responsivity to food cues
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 6 months after treatment completion

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline at 6 months after treatment completion
